item.title: Sandy, Utah Mobile App for iOS
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: The city of Sandy, Utah has a mobile app for iOS devices. I tried it out for a few minutes this morning. The app itself is ok, though doesn’t really look like an iOS app. I suspect it was built with one of the multiplatform SDKs out there. One of the features in the app […]
item.content:encoded:
The city of Sandy, Utah has a mobile app for iOS devices. I tried it out for a few minutes this morning. The app itself is ok, though doesn’t really look like an iOS app. I suspect it was built with one of the multiplatform SDKs out there.

One of the features in the app was to report a problem. I have a cross walk signal at a major intersection near my house that doesn’t work properly, so I used the app to report that. The process wasn’t as smooth as it could have been, but was certainly usable. The ultimate proof is if I hear anything back about it actually getting fixed though.

There are several things that could be done to improve this app, but they aren’t big enough to ruin the overall usefulness of the app. This is a good first version of the app and for something that came out of a city government I’d call it really good.

item.title: Best Bandwidth in Utah?
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: How did Brigham City end up ranking number one for bandwidth in Utah? It’s a small town (2000 Census lists it at 17,412) about half way between Ogden and Logan. So if a little town like that can have an average of 21Mbps how is it that down in Sandy the average is barely 8Mbps […]
item.content:encoded:
How did Brigham City end up ranking number one for bandwidth in Utah? It’s a small town (2000 Census lists it at 17,412) about half way between Ogden and Logan. So if a little town like that can have an average of 21Mbps how is it that down in Sandy the average is barely 8Mbps (ranking 19th!)?

Granted all of is from numbers produced by Speedtest.net, but the sample sizes seem reasonable enough.

I’m sure if I look hard enough I’ll find a way to blame this on Qwest.
